intro: Carex ringgoldiana var. stenandra, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sedge, is a perennial plant native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves that form dense clumps, typically growing in moist to wet soils. This variety is part of the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and related plants. It prefers partial to full shade and is often found in wetlands, marshes, and along stream banks. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers in spikelets, which are typically wind-pollinated.
